attributes.comment:
My husband and I are adopting a child from China. We had completed our
paperwork and have been waiting for a match for almost 12 months now. During
our wait, we realized that our time to wait for a match was likely going to
exceed the time limit for the I-171H. In response to this, we appealed to our
family and friends for help in appealing to our government.

We specifically wrote letters to our congressman, Rep. Tom Tancredo; our
senator, Senator Wayne Allard; the director of the Denver District office of
USCIS, Mr. Mario Ortiz, and the secretary of Homeland Security, Secretary
Michael Chertoff. In essence, we received little in return. Our elected
officials told us there was nothing they could do. We received a form letter
from Mr. Ortiz and the person who responded on Secretary Chertoff's behalf - the
same EXACT form letter was received by family and friends who also appealed on
our behalf. No letter we received addressed our concerns directly and in fact
implied that we should have adopted domestically instead.

We explained that having couples, like us, complete the entire process for a new
I-171H put additional burdens on staff. We explained that this process only
served as a penalty for couples, like us, who have chosen to adopt
internationally when the delay to complete the adoption was not our fault. In
fact, we pointed out according to publication M-249, The Immigration of Adopted
and Prospective Adoptive Children, an international adoption is deemed abandoned
if not completed in the requisite timelines. We have not chosen to abandon our
petition, we are merely waiting and have no control over a foreign government.

The validity of an I-171H was not always 18 months. It was, at a time in
history, only valid for only 12 months. This timeframe was considered inadequate
and it was changed to 18 months. Today, this 18-month time period is equally
inadequate yet nothing is being done to address this issue.

Today, I learned that USCIS wishes to increase their fees for fingerprinting and
for the processing of the I-600A, which must be filled out prior to receiving an
I-171H. There are many feelings rushing through me; omitting expletives, the
two prominent ones are indignation and frustration.

The fee increase is not necessary at this time and amounts to a penalty on those
couple who have chosen to adopt internationally. However, if a fee increase is
inevitable, then perhaps the length of time the I-171H is valid should be
extended to 24 months and, for those who, like us, currently hold a valid
I-171H, be grandfathered into that extended time frame.

Thank you for your time.

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Christine M. Swenson
